reviewText: Maniac Cop 2, in the tradition of Evil Dead 2 and Godfather 2, is one of those sequels that doesn't disappoint and, in many ways, improves on the original. Director William Lustig and Producer/Writer Larry Cohen decide that bigger is, most definitely, better and with a slightly larger budget available, manage to pack the film with death defying, original stunts, joyously over the top, Japanese cartoon style blood squibs and some required 42nd Street style nudity. It's not just the horror, action and exploitation elements that have been expanded either. Lustig and Cohen, both fans of film noir and the Universal monster movies, give Maniac Cop 2 the style and themes of both from the atmospheric cinematography and the, one-liner riddled, scripting to Jay Chattaway's music, which reduces the Maniac Cop whistling motif to only when Cordell is on the prowl and during the rest of the film is a fantastic horn and string filled orchestral score worthy of any of the great noirs of the 40s.Maniac Cop 2 represents the beginning of the end of an era where films this fantastically odd, diverse and action packed could be made at all, let alone on this small of a budget in one of the most expensive cities in the world.Only in the 80s and/or early 90s and only with a creative team this talented behind it do you get a film like this that has elements of horror, action, film noir and comedy, featuring insane car chases on city streets, the demolition of a police station by an automatic pistol wielding zombie cop, a prison fight where the main protagonist is on fire for 5 minutes and even includes a bizarre and wonderful rap song over the end credits and it all actually work. The film is tight, well paced, expertly directed, features a classic Cohen script, with his endearing trait of giving even minor characters back story and impetus and a strong cast, most of whom, play their roles with exactly the right amount of B-Movie, straight faced, loopy melodrama except for a delightfully, mannered and quirky turn by, the always wonderful, Michael Lerner as the pipe smoking police commissioner. Robert Davi and Leo Rossi are also stand outs, with Davi giving the trilby wearing, hard smoking and shrink hating McKinney an expected gruff, hard edge but also an unexpected internal soulfulness and Rossi firing on every cylinder imaginable in his role as the black toothed, whooping, insanely bearded, southern serial killer in 70s duds. The supporting cast that surrounds them, including a lot of Lustig's regular stable of actors, like Lou Bonacki and Charles Napier are also solid and a joy to watch.Lustig and Cohen are film-makers with the old 42nd street coursing through their veins and one of the joys of The Maniac Cop series, as well as other of their works, is seeing New York in its sleazy neon drenched former days and it's incredible;e, by today's standards, the amount they managed to get done on the streets of the city and parts of New Jersey.The film is a tremendously good time with so much packed into its 87 minutes that your jaw will be hanging open in amazement by the time two flaming people crash through a cinder block wall, fall several stories into a prison bus which then, promptly, explodes. They really, and sadly, don't make 'em like this anymore.BLU-RAY REVIEWThe disc is a Blu-Ray/DVD combo pack collector's edition. The presentation of the film is incredible. Having previously only been available on a bare-bones, near 3rd generation VHS quality, budget DVD, for people looking to complete their MC collection (after Synapse's special edition Blu of the first film) or just looking for the perfect edition of a damn fun film then look no further. Blue Underground is the Criterion Collection for lovers of B-Movies, cult and 42nd street films providing the definitive versions of these genre classics. The picture quality is superb with the disc featuring a, newly done, high definition transfer from the original film negatives and the soundtrack is superb. A rich, deep, 7.1 DTS-HD track that not only provides a great surround sound experience but also allows you to pick up on nuances in the score and the dialogue like never before.For lovers of the 'behind the camera' experience, the extras a great too. There's an in-depth making of "Back on the Beat" which reveals both the pleasure and pain of making movies like this. The people are all refreshingly candid and have some entertaining stories to tell. Most of the main cast, William Lustig, Larry Cohen and stunt co-ordinator Spiro Razatos are present and seem to get a big kick out of the fact a film like this, only released on video and HBO originally in the US, still has such a following.To round out the set there's a Q&A; after a screening with Lustig that repeats some of the stories from the 'making of' but also adds some too. He is a warm, funny story teller and there are lots of laughs to be had watching this feature.There's a deleted scene featuring the second Raimi cameo of the series. For people who don't know, film-maker Sam Raimi has a cameo as a reporter in Maniac Cop 1 and his brother, actor Ted Raimi, has a similar cameo in part 3. A cameo was shot for part 2, that echoes the 'people on the street comments' section from the first film, which was removed because of pacing issues, and that's what is presented here.The disc is also region free and should be viewable on any Blu-Ray player worldwide, although this has not been tested by me.If you're even a passing fan of the films, or this genre of film, you'll want to get your hands on this. It's a fantastic, definitive edition.
summary: A superior blu for an underrated genre classic

reviewText: Matt Cordell rises from his watery grave and seeks revenge on those who killed him in the previous entry. He also causes trouble by killing cops and helping the criminals. And when he teams up with a homicidal serial killer, it's up to though cop Sean Mc Kinney and his partner Susan Riley to stop this murderous duo before it's to late.A very entertaining and well acted movie. Better than you'd expect and well directed by William Lustig (Maniac, Uncle Sam)One of the film most memorable scenes is where Matt Cordell causes a massacre at a police station.The Maniac Cop movies are very underated slashers in my opninion. So, if you like other slasher movie series such as Friday The 13th, A Nightmare on Elm Street, Child's Play and Halloween, you should add Maniac Cop 1-3 to your collection as well.
summary: Maniac Cop is back! But this time he has a playmate...

reviewText: Amazon was selling a copy of this rare film for a few weeks. I ordered it with something that had yet to be released and it was gone, Amazon didnt send an email telling me off this. Luckily anther company I trust was selling a brand new copy and I snatched it right away.The film is a good picture quailty but there are no speical features. Just the film and scene selection; Not even a measly trailer was added to the disc. I dont know if they will rerelase this film back on dvd in the near future but i'm happy enough with the copy I got. Good luck finding it right now for a fair price. I seen one or two copies floating around Ebay for more then one hundred dollars.

reviewText: For years I was waiting for a Region 1 release of Maniac Cop 2, a sequel that I consider one of the best horror sequels ever made. I actually refused to buy Maniac Cop 3 on DVD until 2 got released (personal issue, I can't own later entries without the film before). Here it is 2009 and I just found out that there was a Region 1 edition that was released in 2007.What?! A Region 1 DVD was released two years ago and I never heard of it! I am usually on the up-and-up on DVD releases but this news passed me by. It seems to have passed a lot of people by because the DVD was released under the radar and quickly went out-of-print.The DVD release was odd to say the least because it went out-of-print right away. Apparently there are a lot of issues about the copyright ownership of the film hence why excellent companies like Synpase could not afford to obtain the rights. Sadly since the DVD went out-of-print so fast means you're not going to get this DVD for a low price....but for fans it's worth every penny.The DVD was released by First Look Studios (the same company that released Maniac Cop 3) and this is a high quality company. Sadly this DVD doesn't come near their other releases. The DVD is bare bones. No trailer, no special features, and a full screen transfer. Even though it's full screen the picture looks pretty good and is better than VHS.The DVD may be bare bones but it's still worth it for fans to complete the Maniac Cop trilogy. Be prepared to pay a little more money for this ultra rare DVD but with a little searching you can get it for a better price.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Maniac cop 2 finally gets a blu-ray release for the first time ever in the U.S.Blue underground has released this on Blu-ray and given the film a fantastic HD widescreen transferand a new Audio mix 5.1 surround soundand it's also region free, yes it plays on all region blu-ray's, not sure if the DVD is region free i guess it would bebetter quality then previous DVD releases no doubt about it.and this film has not just been given a fantastic HD transfer,there is also a brand new Making of Documentary 45minsfor the first time ever some of the actors from the film are interviewed for this blu-ray releaseinterviews with Bill Lustig, Larry cohen who both talk about the first Maniac cop and this sequel anywayeven thou none of them are interviewed for the synapse Maniac cop blu-raythere's also interviews with Robert Davi, Robert Z'Dar and Claudia christianinterviews with the Stunt man from the film, interview with music composer Jay chatawayan excellent Documentary no fan should missthere's also an Audio commentary by Bill Lustigand a Q&A; featurette with Bill Lustig at a conventionTV spots and trailerDisc 2 of this blue underground release is just the DVD version of the film that's all which i didn't bother watchingi was only interested in the blu-ray version.so scrap the previous dvd releasesand get this Blu-ray release which has all new HD transfer and a new 5.1 surround sound audio mixwhich looks and sounds excellent in my opinioni Gave this blu-ray 5 stars, definitely worth the money.
summary: MANIAC COP 2 FINALLY GETS A BLU-RAY RELEASE

reviewText: Typically in film the sequel proves to be inferior to the original.  Though with Maniac Cop 2 this is not the case.Lets be honest, with a title like Maniac Cop 2 you know exactly what you're getting into.  Chances are you're here because you saw and enjoyed the first film.  This movie takes everything that was great about the original and expands on it.Maniac Cop 2 is truly the perfect B-movie.  You've got an insane zombie cop, serial killer subplot, Bruce Campbell, and great direction by one of the kings of exploitation William Lustig.This one is not to be missed!
summary: What!?  A Sequel that's better than the original?

reviewText: A cut above the average 80's series psycho flicks, this is good fun to look back on and reminisce to the days when there was no mobile phones, twitter or political correctness. Nowadays, the studio would be sued for making police look like deranged lunatics. Let's just remember - it's make-believe, hey?! If you want a modern horror movie designed to send you screaming to the hills, watch the new wave of horror documentaries by Justin Bieber, One Direction, Beyoncé, Katy Perry, etc.

reviewText: First off, I'm not happy that the format is full screen.  That said, I'm just happy to have a copy at all.  I like this series, always have, always will.  Is it great filmmaking, of course not (that's not the point).This sequel literally begins where the first one left off; from out of a watery grave.....Maniac Cop!  He's bent on revenge (finally), having gotten detoured during the first film by a lot of needless killings (warm-ups for the real thing).  He has help in this one in the form of a serial killer (a cackling Leo Rossi).  That's the only sore spot I have concerning this film, Leo Rossi's clichéd bad guy who won't stop cackling (the lazy actor's approach to villainy, when in doubt, bug out your eyes and cackle).Poor Bruce Campbell, he pulls a Janet Leigh and doesn't make it all the way through this feature.  I missed him immediately.  At least Robert Davi more than made up for his absence playing a cop who readily believes Maniac Cop is still on the loose, even if no one will listen to him....until it's too late.I liked that Maniac Cordell was able to take a road trip before once again "dying."  I rate this on par with the original.  I enjoy it for what it is, which is not your state of the art horror flick.

reviewText: Along comes the wonderful Larry Cohen . He writes a terrifically fun , action packed , idea jammed and atmospheric sequel to Maniac Cop that knocks my socks off . I love genre film . I love horror film . I love the silly heart and mind of this absurd and fantastic living comic book . Back when folks were set on fire (for real) to get the shot . Back when T and A counted for something .Super well cast and photographed as well . Strongly recommended to all horror hounds . You know who you are . Solid female characters as well (well before that became "the trend") . See it and glee with it . Outrageous fun friends . Outrageous .

reviewText: I enjoyed Maniac Cop 2. This was a decent sequel to Maniac Cop, starring Bruce Campbell. This movie picks up right where the first film left off. There are some unexpected twists in the story and it is different just enough to stay interesting. In this film Robert Davi does a great job as a main character in this film trilogy. If you liked the first film I can highly recommend that you give this one a viewing. It is better than most sequels tend to be. I have been looking for this movie ever since I bought and watched Maniac Cop. I am glad I was finally able to find it on Amazon.
summary: Decent sequel to a cult classic horror film

reviewText: Amazon does not have this movie listed as being available on DVD, but here in Australia it is! (Regioun 4)I had seen this years ago, but it was a rental on VHS that was overly worn out and the picture & sound was so bad I turned it off halfway through.When I saw this DVD in the really cheap bin ($3, hows that for cheap?) I thought i'd give it a go, it would only be pocket change i'd lose anyway.Review:I expected this to be a bad b-grade horror flick, but I really got into it straight away. It's about a cop named Matt Cordell who was a cop with the NYPD who was setup for something by the head cheif of police or something, and i'm not actualy too sure if he is supposed to be dead, or just scarred or what, but he seems to be a Jason Voorhees style zombie who can't be killed.Matt Cordell is terrorising the city by killing cops. I guess it's his way of revenge against them or something. Along the way he meets a seriol killer who keeps murdering strippers and they become a forgetable duo.Comments: A lot of the events taking place where a bit confusing, I guess I will have to see the original Maniac Cop to fully understand what the flash backs are about and in what order, but neither MC1 or MC3 are available here yet.This is a sequel, and i'm already taking an interest in this saga. It's not brilliant, not exactly original, and the ending of Cordells (supposed) demise I thought was a bit too quick and should have been drawn out with a tighter and bigger ending, but overall, I like it.If your into Freddy, Jason, Chucky, Myers or those type of charactors, then I recomend this film if you havent already seen it, just give it a go and see what you reckon. If your into thriller with a twist and creative plot, then this will not be your thing.Bonus Features: None. Tho it does have the trailer to MC2, MC3 and Strange Bedfellows, but I do not consider trailers a bonus feature, they should just be standard on every DVD.Me Cop II rocks and I cant wait to see the first and 3rd one now!
summary: This Movie IS on DVD In Oz

reviewText: That wacky Matt Cordell is back and he's still pissed at the police department.  After getting revenge on the two cops that put the kabosh on him the first time around, he now has a plan to stick it to city hall by recruiting a serial killer(Leo Rossi) and a death row inmate(Clarence Williams III) to bust into Sing Sing.  There he'll finally be able to trash those scumbags that cut him up.  Two new officers come into play this time around.  A police psychologist played by Claudia Christian and a hard boiled Stetson wearing detective played by the always reliable Robert Davi("Detective Johnson....no the other one").The writer/director team of Larry Cohen and Bill Lustig returned for this sequel, so that's a plus.  The film may be a bit of a rehashing of the first film, but enough new elements are introduced to keep it interesting.  In fact this film is way better than it probably should be, but we can credit that to Cohen and Lustig.  Davi is always fun, though he's playing a rather stereotypical detective.  The addition of psycho Leo Rossi is a nice touch.  He becomes a kind of Renfield type character to Cordell.  Bruce Campbell returns, as does his partner played by Laurene Landon, but both roles are only a bit more than cameos.  Michael Lerner also joins the cast as one of the officials who originally framed Cordell.  And of course, the great Robert Z'Dar returns as Cordell, the Maniac Cop.  His makeup job is a little more elaborate and grotesque this time around, definitely reinforcing that he's more a zombie here than a living person(the first film played with the idea that Cordell may either be a walking dead guy or just so hardcore badazz that he's not easily killed).I can't really see anyone who liked Maniac Cop not getting some entertainment from the sequel.  Some say it's even better.  I still prefer the original film, but as a sequel this movie is quite impressive.
Title: N/A

reviewText: In Maniac Cop (1988), former New York City cop Matt Cordell (Robert Z'Dar) began a violent killing spree that is continued in the sequel, Mania Cop 2 (1990), which delivers more of the same cruel violence, in mostly dark and gritty settings.  Spoilers follow, so stop here if you must.Cordell, who had a pipe run into his chest, before taking a plunge into a river, is believed dead.  Following procedures, Commissioner Edward Doyle (Michael Lerner) has police officers Jack Forrest (Bruce Campbell) and Teresa Mallory (Laurene Langdon), who tangled with the Maniac Cop in the first film, see clinical psychologist Susan Riley (Claudia Christian) for evaluation.  Forrest believes Cordell is dead, while a still traumatized Mallory feels the Maniac Cop is still alive.  Cordell is far from dead, and picks up where he left off, brutally slaying Officer Forrest.  Detective Sean McKinney (Robert Davi) is assigned to the case, where Mallory is next on Cordell's hit list.  Mallory however, doesn't go down without a fight, as she races with Cordell in stolen cab, and then takes him on with a chainsaw, before having her neck snapped.  Susan Riley barely escapes death, after taking a wild ride handcuffed to the steering wheel of a runaway car, in a pretty impressive stunt sequence.Writer Larry Cohen and director William Lustig, who collaborated on the first film, continue to work well together, although the story takes a strange twist, when Cordell teams up with serial killer Steven Turkell (Leo Rossi).  Turkell has been murdering strippers, and while attempting to strangle a stripper named Cheryl (Paula Trickey), Cordell mysteriously appears, and helps Turkell evade capture by the police.  Crashing for a while at Turkell's pad, it is revealed how Cordell received injuries while in Sing Sing prison.Turkell is arrested at a strip club, and while in a holding cell visiting with Riley, accurately predicts that Cordell will soon arrive to break him out.  The Maniac Cop enters the station house with guns blazing, and leaves behind a pile of dead cops.  Turkell and a few other cons put on police uniforms, and board a bus headed to Sing Sing.  Led by Cordell, and with Riley as hostage, the bus arrives at the prison for the film's fiery conclusion.Maniac Cop 2 starts out very strong, nicely addressing the leftover elements, and introducing the new players.  The story takes some odd twists in the middle, to arrive at an explosive conclusion in Sing Sing prison.  Cordell isn't really a team player, but he manages to make Turkell a tool in his plan, and the talkative killer is also used to communicate to the audience, the reasons behind what is happening.  The conclusion seems a bit hurried and a little silly, but overall the Maniac Cop 2 is a brutal and violent tale that pretty much delivers most of what fans of the original might expect, garnering a rating of 3.5 stars.  Although laid to rest with full honors, Matt Cordell would return again in Maniac Cop 3: Badge of Silence (1993), a project that would see director William Lustig walk off the film.
summary: Matt Cordell continues his bloody quest for vindication...

reviewText: Having seen the original Maniac Cop, I say honestly that this is a very good sequel. It picks up literally right where the original film leaves off, with much of the surviving cast and continues the story from there.There's lots of tie in the original and the story and plot are both fairly decent. The cinematography and effects are probably even better than the first film and there is definitely more action this time around.These sequels have been really hard to find, for some time now, so if you're a fan I suggest picking them up while you can. The DVD for this film was, as has been noted, very bare bones. No extra features to speak of, but at least the movie is available. The quality of the movie itself in terms of video is very good and the audio is up to par as well. If anything, I'm glad they didn't go cheap in that department.All around, this is a truly worthy sequel to the original Maniac Cop and should be in your collection if you're a fan of the original. Get it while you can!
summary: Worthy sequel to the amazing original!
